results.name: Smallest nontrivial extension of n which is prime.
comment: The argument in A069695 shows that a(n) always exists. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 11 2020
link: Chai Wah Wu, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 [T. D. Noe computed the first 1000 terms]
Chai Wah Wu, On a conjecture regarding primality of numbers constructed from prepending and appending identical digits, arXiv:1503.08883 [math.NT], 2015.
Index entries for primes involving decimal expansion of n
example: For n = 1, we could append 1, 3, 7, 9, 01, etc., to make a prime, but 1 gives the smallest of these, 11, so a(1) = 11.
For n = 2, although 2 is already prime, the definition requires an appending at least one digit. 1 doesn't work because 21 = 3 * 7, but 3 does because 23 is prime. Hence a(2) = 23.
maple: f:= proc(n) local x0, d, r, y;
for r from 1 to 10^d-1 by 2 do
mathematica: A030665[n_] := Module[{d = 10, nd = 10 * n}, While[True, x = NextPrime[nd]; If[x < nd + d, Return[x]]; d *= 10; nd *= 10]]; Array[A030665, 100] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 19 2016, translated from _Chai Wah Wu_'s Python code *)
results.author: _Patrick De Geest_
